data.title: East Timor: hell to paradise
data.meta_description: Timor Lorosa'e became a free and independent new nation last month - that's the proper name for East Timor, created with the help of a United (...)
data.text:
East Timor has been a sovereign and democratic state since 20 May. Now that it is on the road to normality, there may be less international interest in this half-island and its 737,000 inhabitants. Although, as one of the Lesser Sunda islands separating Southeast Asia and the south Pacific, this tiny nation has great strategic importance.

In many ways developments there over the past three years have been good. In Dili, the capital, parliamentary representatives from 12 of the 16 political parties have been meeting since last August’s legislative elections. A president — although with limited powers — has been elected democratically; a constitution has been drawn up; the constituent assembly has opted for a semi-presidential system; and a government drawn from the assembly’s majority party (Fretilin, the Revolutionary Front for East Timorese Independence) has been set up with Mari Alkatiri as its prime minister.

The island was a Portuguese colony for four centuries before being occupied by Japan during the second world war. On 7 December 1975 it was invaded by Indonesia, which sought to turn it into a military base, and 200,000 Timorese (almost one-third of the population) were massacred. Indonesia’s invasion would not have been possible without the assent of the United States, which for over 20 years armed and trained the Indonesian military units fighting East Timor’s pro-independence forces. Pentagon and US state department documents, declassified in 1999, show that Indonesia’s President Suharto sent his troops in with the consent of the then US president, Gerald Ford, and the secretary of state, Henry Kissinger, who visited the Indonesian capital of Jakarta on the eve of the invasion.
